title: How to Adjust a Hot Water Heater

steps.title: Consider whether your water temperature is in need of adjusting.
steps.content: Consider whether your water temperature is in need of adjusting. For safety reasons, most manufacturers recommend that the water you use in your homestay at around 120 °F (49 °C). Most water heaters will already be set to this temperature when they’re installed. To limit the risk of injury, it’s best to just leave it alone in most cases. [1] X Research source If your water seems unusually cold, the problem may be a broken heating element or poor insulation rather than the temperature of the water heater itself. A qualified plumber can help diagnose and repair a faulty water heater. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Twist the dial on the bottom of the water heater to change the temperature.
steps.content: Twist the dial on the bottom of the water heater to change the temperature. Gas water heaters are easy—they feature a single knob that controls the amount of heat being directed to the unit. Turning this knob to the left (counterclockwise) will crank up the temperature, making the water hotter. Turning it to the right (clockwise) will cool it down. On the majority of gas water heaters, the lower temperature range will be somewhere around 90–110 °F (32–43 °C), while the upper range will top out at around 140–150 °F (60–66 °C). The dial on your gas water heater may not be numbered, which can make finding the perfect temperature a little tricky. One simple way around this is to take the temperature of the water a few times after altering your settings, then tag the exact degree reading or mark it on the dial itself. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Increase the temperature to enjoy warmer water for cleaning and bathing.
steps.content: Increase the temperature to enjoy warmer water for cleaning and bathing. There are a couple advantages of having hotter water in your home. For one, it can make a shower or soak in the tub more luxurious, since you won’t have to worry about running out of hot water as quickly. It can also give appliances that don’t use preheated water (like dishwashers and washing machines) a boost, which will help get dirty items cleaner. Hotter temperatures are more effective for eliminating most common bacteria, including health hazards like Legionella, E. coli, and staphylococcus. [4] X Research source Avoid setting your water heater to a temperature higher than 120 °F (49 °C). Doing so can present a serious risk of burns, especially for children and the elderly. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Decrease the temperature to save money on your utilities.
steps.content: Decrease the temperature to save money on your utilities. Heating large quantities of water gets expensive fast. If you’re looking to shave a few dollars off your next heating bill, consider lowering your water heater’s temperature setting to the 100–110 °F (38–43 °C) range. Even a small change can save you big over the course of a few months. [6] X Trustworthy Source U.S. Department of Energy Official site for the U.S. Department of Energy, which provides resources related to energy safety, conservation, and efficiency Go to source Keep in mind that your water won’t get as hot, which may impact your comfort or the level of sanitation for cleaning projects.

steps.title: Shut off the power to the water heater.
steps.content: Shut off the power to the water heater. Head to your home’s central circuit breaker and locate the switch corresponding to the water heat. Flip this switch to the “Off” position. This will cut off the electricity flowing to the unit, allowing you to open it up without fear of being zapped. Don’t attempt to make any alterations to your water heat before double checking that the power is safely off. If the breaker for your water heater isn’t labeled, it may be necessary to use a multimeter to test for a live current. You’re looking for a reading of zero volts. Don’t forget to tag the correct breaker when you’re done. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the access panel from the side of the unit.
steps.content: Remove the access panel from the side of the unit. Identify the two screws at the top and bottom of the panel and use a flat-blade screwdriver to loosen them. [8] X Research source Pull the panel free from the body of the unit and set it aside somewhere nearby. Be careful not to lose the screws. On some models, there may be a separate plastic cover beneath the metal access panel. This should come away easily with a gentle tug.

steps.title: Pull out or push aside the insulation covering the thermostat.
steps.content: Pull out or push aside the insulation covering the thermostat. Inside the water heater, you’ll find a thicker layer of insulation. If it’s a single piece made from styrofoam or similar material, you’ll be able to simply lift it out. Move fiberglass insulation out of the way by hand to clear a path to the thermostat controls. [9] X Research source The insulation inside a water heater is used to reduce heat loss and ensure more accurate readings.

steps.title: Use a flat-blade screwdriver to raise or lower the temperature setting.
steps.content: Use a flat-blade screwdriver to raise or lower the temperature setting. The high- and low-end temperature ranges will be displayed at the bottom of the thermostat. Insert the tip of the screwdriver into the colored adjusting screw to change the temperature. Twisting it to the left (counterclockwise) will decrease the temperature while twisting it to the right (clockwise) will increase it. [10] X Research source The adjusting screws on newer electric water heaters feature indicator hands which tell you approximately how hot the current setting is. Pay attention to where the hand rests, as this will allow you to fine-tune your water temperature more precisely. If your water heater makes use of dual heating elements, make sure both thermostats are set to the same temperature so that one isn’t forced to do more work than the other.

steps.title: Replace the insulation and access panel.
steps.content: Replace the insulation and access panel. When you’re satisfied with the new temperature setting, put everything back the way you found it. Make sure the insulation is completely covering the internal thermostat, then fit both protective covers back into place and tighten the screws to secure them.

steps.title: Restore the power to the water heater.
steps.content: Restore the power to the water heater. Return to your main breaker and toggle the switch for the water heater to the “On” position. The electricity will once again be live, so avoid making any further tweaks after this point. It may take up to an hour for your running water to reach its maximum temperature after having your unit shut off for an extended period.

steps.title: Fill a glass with hot water.
steps.content: Fill a glass with hot water. Turn on the tap nearest to the water heater and allow it to run for a full minute. Once it’s as hot as it can get, hold a drinking glass or similar container under the stream until you’ve caught a few inches. For the most accurate reading possible, it’s best to use a container that’s been kept at room temperature.

steps.title: Insert a cooking thermometer into the hot water.
steps.content: Insert a cooking thermometer into the hot water. Have your thermometer on standby so you can drop it in as soon as you’ve filled the container. Make sure the probe is fully submerged, then wait 30-60 seconds for it to gauge the temperature. [11] X Research source Write down the number you get for reference. It can help you work out the ideal temperature range for your home, or point to potential heating issues outside of the unit itself. If you don’t place the thermometer in the water right away, the water may have a chance to cool down enough to throw off your reading.

steps.title: Determine whether the water is hot enough.
steps.content: Determine whether the water is hot enough. Assuming that the temperature is at or around 120 °F (49 °C), you can rest assured that your water heater is performing up to snuff. Any lower than that and it may need to be bumped up a few degrees. Remember that temperatures exceeding 120 °F (49 °C) will be too intense for most home. Increase your water temperature in 10 degree increments to reduce the risk of scalding.

steps.title: Wait 3 hours before retesting the water temperature.
steps.content: Wait 3 hours before retesting the water temperature. It will take a little time for your water heater to catch up to the new temperature setting, so be patient while it reaches the desired warmth. In the meantime, hold off on running a bath or operating any appliances in case the water being circulated is hotter than you intended. [12] X Research source Take care of any necessary adjustments before everyone in your home begins their daily routine.
